title: Before 1 October 2018, will Kim Jong-un cease to be supreme leader of North Korea?
preds: 10 days to go, even a heart attack would take longer
Minimal chance of this happening in the next 20 days.
Unless he dies of natural causes or someone from inside attempt a successful assassination him, it is not possible.

The most likely collapse of the North Korean state would come from the inside, specifically through reactions to economic reforms that would destabilize and de-legitimize the regime. Economic reforms are proving to be necessary to continue presenting his regime as legitimate now that he has effective nuclear weapons. These reforms would not happen at such a rapid pace so as to provoke a coup to depose Kim Jong-un within the next month, but they could cause political instability. It is still unclear what reforms would be undertaken, so I do not think that Kim Jong-un will leave his post as supreme leader of North Korea by 1 October 2018.

At one month out, we want to know the percentage chance a dictator will die or be deposed within a one month time period.  Annual risk of death for someone 35 years old is about 1/1000 for an American.  Given Kim's affluent  lifestyle and BMI, we are probably similar to that distribution.  So for a one month period that is about 1/10,000, but neglects the chance of political death, which is probably higher.
Kim Jong Un-type leaders often finish their career with surprising events. But usually there are many similar situations, that can lead to their finish, no one knows which one will be the dead end.

Empirical data on autocratic regime duration indicate a higher level than mixed regime types.   These observations allow us to infer and support (through hypothesis testing) that autocratic regimes (with repression as its primary means of coercion) are stable and that the variance in durability and repressive coercion for be different than anocratic (mixed regime types) systems which tend toward instability where repressive coercion also exists.  Whether there is a significant difference in variance should be determined the appropriate empirical test.  If none exists, we can ascertain difficulties in the formulation of this proposition; if it exists, it provides evidence for demarcation among regime types.  It also provides validity for the concept.  Falsifiability is the main criterion for determine the validity of any hypothesis. This empirical regularity has been falsified through a mix of testing methodologies.  This proposition is useful in assertaining the interest and strategic interactions among regime types.

There have only been three North Korean leaders since 1948. The previous leader, Kim Jong-il, was in power for 17 and a half years. Before him, Kim Il-sung was in power for nearly 46 years. Kim Jong-un has only been in power for 6 years; based on the country's history, he likely has at least another decade. As a dictator, Kim Jong-un has no reason to abdicate power. Moreover, the population doesn't have the means (insititutions, formal or informal) to organize and dicatate a transfer of power in the span of 6 months (meeting the October deadline of this question). Additionally, Kim Jong-un's recent trip to China and discussions (and planned meeting) with the U.S. are sending a signal to the international community of a potential willingness to cooperate on the issue of denuclearization which reduces the international desire for his removal from power.
Really don't see this happening at all

Kim Jong-un has been a very stern successor after his father and has largely solidified his rule over North Korea. The only real possibility of Kim Jong-un stepping down would be in an overthrow of his rule, which could become a possibility either from an uprising within the Communist Party or a popular revolt. In order for a popular revolt to have any chance of occurring, the economic conditions in North Korea must become very dire and they certainly are on their way, especially with the new rounds of sanctions by the West and China's willingness to begin enforcement of their sanctions as well. However, it can be assumed that a dictator such as Kim Jong-un would have an interest in prolonging his rule for as long as possible. Therefore, he must raise the living standards of the North Korean people, which can only be achieved through negotiation on the possible removal of sanctions. So far, Kim Jong-un has been willing to compromise and hold talks. He sent a delegation to South Korea for the Olympics and will be meeting with the South Korean President at the end of April. There are also negotiations underway for Kim Jong-un to meet with President Trump after his meeting with the South Korean leader. Although the sudden shift in policy may be surprising, North Korean defector Ri Jong Ho sees this as perfectly understandable. Ri explains that North Korea's economy is in a dire situation and Kim Jong-un has an interest in preserving his rule. Kim Jong-un remains distrustful of China and believes that the US will be instrumental in his ability to retain power. Ri's revelations show that Kim Jong-un is aware of the problems facing his country and he is willing to negotiate. However, talks and negotiation may not be enough to lift sanctions. South Korean Prime Minister Lee Nak-yon has stated that talks must be followed by substantive action and despite Kim Jong-un's willingness to negotiate, he must also be willing to make compromises. Whether Kim Jong-un agrees to such compromises remains to be seen, however, there is a possibility with talks underway for substantive action to occur, and if they do, would certainly extend his rule for the foreseeable future.

Earlier I predicted a 3% chance, but I'm actually raising the probability slightly to 7% because the U.S. and North Korea are set to have nuclear talks by the end of May. This is a welcome move and could improve diplomatic relations between the two nations, but it's also a very high-stakes meeting. If the two countries make an agreement and then North Korea breaks it, which the country has been known to do, the probability of conflict may increase. More importantly one expert argues, "If North Korea does decide to give up nuclear weapons in exchange for a security guarantee from the US and then they open up the country, think about how much political influence South Korea will try to wage, think of Western society rushing in and the influence of outside information." Further, he argues that newly empowered North Koreas will find financial liberation and could mobilize to overthrow North Korea's leader. However, I still doubt North Korea would give up its weapons and that North Korean citizens would be able to mobilize in the four months between June 1 and October 1. Plus, I doubt foreign nations will attempt to intervene with the upcoming historic talk.

In the past few weeks, the North Korean leader has taken several steps to reach out to countries like South Korea and the United States. These meetings show a new trend towards warming relations with the outside world, limiting the likelihood that a foreign country would act drastically at a time when diplomatic efforts seem to be more effective than ever. State collapse, assassination, or military coup are possible from the inside alone, but unlikely.
The possibility still exists, but it is so small that I am confident in saying zero.  However, I will not be surprised either way.

The spring, however, is the traditional period for deterring any North Korean mobilizations. I previously predicted 5% yes for this question and am now updating my prediction to 2% yes. I lowered the likelihood of my prediction due to the current success of North Korean participation in the Olympics in South Korea. I believe that North and South Korea growing closer and becoming more optimistic towards their relations even further reduces the chances of foreign intervention, assassination, or military coup removing Kim Jong-un as leader of North Korea. If South Korea maintains calm and productive diplomatic relations with North Korea, it is highly unlikely that any South Korean allies, such as Japan or the U.S., would intervene to remove Kim Jong-un. Further, Kim Jong-un still maintains tight control over North Korean elites and the military, so military coup or assassination remain extremely unlikely. Finally, improved North and South Korean relations if anything (although it is unlikely) could cause leniency in sanctions and North Korean economic opening, which could possibly reduce the chances of total North Korean state collapse. So far, the successful North and South Korean cooperation in these Olympics makes it even less likely than before the games began that Kim Jong-un will cease to lead North Korea.

Kim Jong-un will stay the supreme leader of NK. First looking at statistics of leadership exit: Kim Jong-un was born in either 1884-1986 making him roughly 32 years old, while the average life expectancy of a NK male is 67 years old (as of 2015). I note this because of previous dictators who have died while in office (Muammar Gaddafi killed by his people, Saddam Hussein an American fault, Pol Pot, etc.). It would be useful to include statistical evidence of authoritative leaders being kicked out of office - the Americans have kicked 7 dictators out of office. Neither of these countries are world leaders - Iran (considered power). Given 10 years - more possible Jong-un will be kicked out: Thae Yong Ho, the highest-level diplomatic official said there have been anti-workers parties and anti-revolutionary events and most NK watch South Korean news despite the repercussions.

Seems highly unlikely. Most likely scenario resulting in Kim Jong-un removal would be an internal coup. However, recent noted missile success seems to tamp down possibility of coup.

Kim has done a good job of making it difficult for any successful conspiracy to get off the ground within North Korea, disfavoring internal methods of overthrow (particularly coups). External intervention, though not impossible, is not unlikely. China's stated policy in the event of a conflict between NK and the USA (they will intervene in favor of whoever doesn't fire the first shot) provides a stabilizing influence disfavoring regime change through conflict; this effect is magnified by the reluctance of either China or South Korea to absorb the least-developed North Korea and its population (an event which would make the difficulties of German reunification pale by comparison). However, health issues and/or lone wolf assassins cannot be completely discounted, particularly in light of recent high-profile defections at the DMV.

Given the recent cooperation between the DPRK and South Korea in the Olympics, there is a high likelihood that both sides will seek to de-escalate tensions and keep dialogue open through the remainder of 2018. However, a continued decline in the DPRK economy and/or political infighting could grow to pose an existential risk to Kim Jong-Un's leadership.

It is very unlikely that Kim Jong-Un will cease to be leader of North Korea before 1 October 2018. He has tight control over the military and successfully utilizes fear as a tactic to control elites and authorities in his government. These factors minimize the chances of military coup or assassination by someone within North Korea. Due to Kim Jong-Un's highly consolidated power and revenue from illicit economic dealings, total state collapse seems unlikely as well, at least before October 1. Foreign intervention is also extremely unlikely due to the difficulties of choosing and installing a credible new leader and dealing with the dire economic situations of North Korean citizens. In my opinion, the most likely end to his tenure would be an abrupt change in his health.

There is a small chance that Kim Jong-un would cease to be the Supreme Leader of North Korea due to the internal threats of a military coup or assassination. The chances of a foreign intervention or state collapse are slim due to the fact that a refugee crisis into China and South Korea would likely ensue, which both countries would want to avoid at all costs. The more things change, the more they stay the same. It would take some radical decision-making for Kim Jong-un to cease being the Supreme Leader of North Korea.

For us to believe that Kim Jong-un ceases to be leader by October 1st 2018, one of the following needs to occur:
(i) Kim Jong-un dies of natural causes -- I rate this as a very unlikely scenario as Kim Jong-un is relatively young and seemingly active/health (though somewhat obese) and would need extraordinary circumstances for this to change within the next ~10 months. Among wealthy nations the mortality rate of a 30-35 y.o. male is ~0.15%. Health/nutrition/standard of living among the NK elite is generally in line with people in wealthier nations therefore this is a safe mortality estimate given what we credibly know about Kim Jong-un.
(ii) Internal conflict deposes Kim Jong-un -- Historically despite challenging domestic (poor economy, famine, energy scarcity) and international (tensions with SK, US, Japan, China) factors, the Kim family has retained strong control over NK. Following a bloody purge of officials and family, especially with ties to China, Kim Jon-un has centralized power around himself and appears more secure today than even this time last year, which leads to...
(iii) Chinese intervention deposes Kim Jong-un -- China kept Kim Jong-un's exiled brother as a bargaining chip and/or backup for a Chinese-backed regime change. Kim Jong-un publicly assassinated his brother to not only eliminate him from play but to publicly flaunt international norms and send a strong signal to China against intervening in NK. Xi Jinping likely won't make a hasty decision with a nuclear power directly across their border.
(iv) Another intervention deposes Kim Jon-un -- e.g., US military conflict. Low probability as NK military power is geared toward aggressive defense (loud bark to avoid nuclear bite) and will not have the capability of accurately delivering a nuclear payload to e.g. the US within that time frame, as such in the absence of irrational behavior by key decision makers this would not be an expected outcome.

1. Dictators with a cult of personality do not leave office until they die or are forced out. See Ludwig, King of the Mountain. 
2. Sanctions strengthen dictators within their country. Kim is a demi-god in their mythology. And sanctions are a kind of attack. As Ghandi said, "It worked on the British because they have a conscience." Sanctions are similar. Starving people don't rise up unless conditions are right. Read your Stalin. 
3. Sanctions and closed borders create opportunities on the black market. I've seen this pretty up close in other places. The idea that sanctions are really what they are on paper is laughable. That kind of thinking is a product of people in the Western world who never lived in a poor area.  Neither Russia nor China has that good of control over their border if they want to. It's like ours with cocaine. 
4. The USA supports the coup in Ukraine (with stationing of the US vice president's son in the country to collect Burisma oil stock and get rich). The USA calls the people of Ukraine who did not overthrow their government, "the rebels" which is full Orwellian doublespeak. The USA then sanctioned Russia for taking Crimea back after the province voted to do that overwhelmingly. Ukraine is the soft underbelly of Russia and Russia was promised it would be off limits. This put Russia on a war footing, because Russia has been invaded multiple times from Europe. This showed Russia and China that US words mean nothing and they cannot trust us. So, they adjusted. NK was a pain in the ass to Russia for most of its post-soviet period. But now, NK serves a purpose. Saber-rattling mad dog to distract the white house and cause trouble. A dangerous dog because NK has been able to hit some major cities in Russia for a while. 
5. China has also paid attention to Ukraine. China and Russia both see the Ukraine revolution as a sign of US aggression intending to overthrow them. China wants to expand its sphere into the  South China Sea. So, China also rediscovered the utility of NK. For a long time China's interest was declining. NK has had nuclear missiles aimed at Beijing for a long time. Starting with Obama's South China sea confrontation, what happened? NK postured and the US press went nuts and the White House got overwhelmed. Tillerson and Trump beat the drums against China trade, and boom. NK forces Tillerson to come on bended knee for help. All very jolly for China. 
6. The more sanctions we put on NK, the more we put Kim Jong-Un in the hands of Russia and China, mostly China. He has to dance for his dinner. 
7. China and Russia both want NK right where it is. NK has a job, and that job is to be a bulwark against US troops on the continent. China will not allow US troops to be within driving distance of Beijing any more than we would let Chinese troops do that to Washington, DC. 
8. Even in the unlikely event that the Trump administration actually convinces Kim that he has no better option than to launch his missiles at the USA and all the US installations in the Pac Rim, Kim will survive. I rather think China prefers to have the USA as a trading partner, but Kim won't die in any war. China would sweep down the peninsula with their troops to occupy it, and they would put Kim under house arrest for the rest of his life.

Base rate: average dictatorship length is 12.5 years according to: http://summitlake.com/wp_1commentary/?p=534.

Historically,  a measure of a dictator's success is their ability to thwart the constant overthrow plans. The assassination article referred to in the intro is from 2016, and since then North Korea has cozied up to none other than Putin and the KGB to beef up security. For the Russians, it's because they see the fall of Jong-Un as an opening on the Russian/N. Korean border from the US military. It's also for that reason that the Russians will not allow the North Korean government to collapse, but they will extract a price for that protection. Interestingly, North Korea is seen as pulling away from China, another formidable protector - but also a tricky one. It looks like the biggest threat North Korea faces is not the ouster of KJU, but of becoming the puppet of the Russian leader, who will see every advantage to keep a good puppet in his place. The recent opening of a trade market with Russia has dramatically increased the North Korean economy and at the same time been a fraying of the relationship with China. That increased economic power will help KJU keep the military in check as the resources become available to wheel and deal.

not a small question!
A peace-loving, healthy young dictator may have 98% chance of lasting a year.
Risk of popular or military insurgence? There are no broadcast reports of recent mass increases in poverty or starvation. There may be unrest with increased communication to the rest of the world. 'Songun' appears to be a deep-rooted belief or fantasy which supports the 'military class' - provides national focus and reduces the risk of military coup. Say 2-5% probability each year.
A happy ending - reunification with the south on the condition of Mr. Kim's departure? Less than 1% in the time-frame provided. A verifiable disarmament (plus abandonment of Songun and exile for Mr. Kim)? About the same as for Mr. Hussein in 2001/2002.
Foreign intervention  - from China, independently? 0-5%. From South Korea - absolutely not over the next year: the losses are already unthinkable. From USA? Rational analysis yields less benefit/loss than for no intervention. However, history indicates benefits are usually exaggerated and losses underestimated. If the decision is driven in part by US internal politics, then timing is a large question. My initial assessment is there may be 1/4 to 1/2 chance of intervention resulting in Mr. Kim's departure by the end of 2018, and the probability may increase as 2018 progresses. Many factors are involved.

If this were to happen it would be through external force, and China would have to agree to a quid quo pro with the United States that I would find extremely unlikely.  China would need to rapidly cross the Yalu river, fortify their border, and seize the DPRK's military assets.  Simultaneously, US forces would have to launch a decapitation strike in an area in which Chinese forces would be active.  The quid pro quo would be that the 38th parallel be observed with the US retreating south of that after military operations, and agreeing to the continued governance of North Korea by a more Chinese friendly (possibly militarily led) government.  This would be also predicated on the removal of THAAD systems which deters China's offensive missile capability and a concomitant reduction of American forces in the South.  Thus, absent any internal opposition capable of rebellion, this sounds like quite a fairy tale...
